Journal of a trip to Pikes Peak by James Owen
May 24 and 25 1860 Some of our party left Chicago by the Chicago Burlington & Quincy RR 4 o'clock P.W. 24 day of May 1866 the party consisted of 7 Individuals, namely James P. Owen & Son, John Williams, L. E. Pappin O. P. Williams, Robert Owens, Mike Franey, Mathew Goar?, the latter two being paperhangers. James P. Owen & Son left at 9h 15m PM of the same day by Express, and united with the party at Mendota, here we had a thunderstorm/transition? unclear Storms and Rain that continued for some ten hours the course of the storm seemed to be in the same direction as our own. West & South of Galesburgh the whole country suffers dreadfully for the want of rain, none having fallen near Quincy for many months. Some part of the Country is litterally parched with the drought there were many Cribs of Corn of the largest dimentions, say from 1 to 2 thousand Bushel each, within 50 miles of Galesburgh it is said here that there are many larger than those we saw along the Road waiting shipment some estimated to contain 250 thousand Bul.?. So I judge that corn will not be higher this year. The City of Quincy is quite a place for the West we judge that it contains about 8 thousand inhabitants, tho we have had no means to determine the facts. Authorities differing from 6 to 20 thousand. The market held in the morning at from 4 to 9 o'clock seemed well supplied with meat greengrocers?, fish, etc.We saw a larger lot of green peas? offered for sale they looked tempting? to us northerners. We arrived here at Quincy last night, at 9 o'clock and were received on board the Boat the same evening by a set of unclear fronting subofficials andliquor beggars. in the morning we found the Captain a polite gentleman willing to see things right? also his clerk & steward we left Quincy about? 6 o'clock A.M. for Hannibal on board the Lady Pike and arrived at the latter city about 11 A.M.

for our teams in the city Hannibal altho we offerd 20p per/ea? bale they say that 2p for small bales is the price when there is any in the city. about 9 o'clock a Thunder Storm came up and a little Rainfall for about 60 miles of the way. Weather all day often fairly hot the party all well
May 27 Thursday! we arrived here this morning all well.  Most of the party formed their Beds on the floor of the unclear Cars all? last night and slept well. the weather here today is very oppressive, altho there is quite a breeze and plenty of dust and it is amazing? to see the yellow sand of the Missouri River banks rising up in clouds and looking almost like cloud of gold and flying to the west. We are disappointed? in the appearance? of the Missouri it has not the Majestic appearance we expected to find. the Mississippi from Quincy to Hannibal is much better. Still we thought the Father of Waters was rather smaller than represented generally. 
28 Monday Today we are very bussy getting our things packed on the wagons for a path? across the Missouri. The weather a little better but warm and dreadful windy so much so that the ferry boat was blown on a sand bar this evening and we were unable to get across. Party all well.  Thermometer? 89
29 Tuesday we crossed the River this morning with difficulty, being to heavy loaded we met a little accident with our unclear unclear waggon axle which detained us 1/2 a day. the Roads are excelent nothing can be fr...g? Thermometer? 71 
30 Wednesday We camped? last night some 12 miles West of the river. Loading constant? unclear we are to heavy loaded. Road good grass plenty. at 12 today we are oblige to leave some 800 unclear of our luggage in storage.

Illinois from this point appears woody. We can see the bluffs in the eighth? 31 Thursday We made good progress today the weather cooler. Thermometer in the afternoon 60
Road good grass plenty as a splendid country nothing I have ever seen can compare with this part of Kansas. The only defientry buy wood/word? it is more Rockey? than Illinois and vastly handsome.
June 1 Friday, Today we passed the Kenekuk mission some forty miles West of the River. Tho a unclear County it looks like a Gentleman's park in England. Such splendid broad well traversed? Road and a County with all that nature could do to beautify one exhausts every moment that Lovers? spend?.  Mansions? is about to make it app/aff...? but here we traval miles without seeing a house or a human being. This cannot last long. Shall camp this evening on the Grasshopper or Walnut Creek. Thermometer 89 with a good breeze.
2 Saturday. Camped on Walnut Creek. all well.  Our course has been all the time on a high Ridge

a drop of water in the beds. and one is surprised when he finds himself crossing a Sandy bottom seen to be a River, the Whole country is Sadly in want of Rain this Year the inhabitants say that they have had Very little for the last 10 [?Mos.?]  this night we stop at the lone tree about 10 Miles from Big Sandy River.  The day hot but fine breese  Thermometer 91  Our days March is about 27 to 31 Miles,
9  Friday, last night we  had quite a Storm of thunder Lightning and Strong Wind, our tent kept up altho we were momentarily expecting to be blown by the storm  several tents in our neighborhood were blown down, and by the way all the [?] are [?] from Civilization still lot from plenty of Company the Road are full of Emigrants Civil War soldiers and it is [three unclear words] Company with 2 americans or long  in a better Idea 50 horses [?] and a 100 Oxen with Teamsters, [?] &c    And before we have all fixed up our tents and Started our fires those cattle and horses Covering the Shore at times it looked like a city or Market place then in the Morning at 7 oClock [?] all is [?] and place visited by the Wolf &c  all [?] like a Virginian    We Saw a [?] Wolf to day but to fire to lose a shot he cross over Road Some di. [?] across and condescended  to look a [three unclear words]  his demeanor was that of a Sheep killer I [?] daily shot prairie doves & plover, which are plenty and from these there is no famine in the Road   We stoped  today at Harington Ranch  Weather evidently altered  Some [?] Rain.  Thermometer 83 at Noon
9 Saturday  We Start to-day for the Banks of the little Blue Which is a River that takes its Rise in Nebraska and flows South from the big blue and then [?] and enters Kansas and  by the by I should have told you that we are  in Nebraska Territory some days.  Whiskey Run was the first stopping place made by us in this Ter. to [?] this place the territorial line [?] and Certainly Kansas is fair

June 4  Uniformity of Landscape, the Climate is Very fine at this time of the Year   the Sun is Very powerful blistering of our ears and [?] nose.  Get a fine cool breese all day so as to make it very comfortable to labor our Teams Seldom sweat except under the Collar   Thermometer Today 92.  all the party well
5 Tuesday.  We Camped at Cotton Wood the feature of country the Same daily   We are traveling on what is called here a Divide that is a ridge with hills Valley & Ravines rising from the flat top on each side and this arrangement is uniform the Whole of the Way excepting an occasional break through by Rivers & Creek   We were visited today with a Small tornado of dust and Sand blowing dustily in our faces, and with Such force that it Started the blood from My bridle Hand in several places when we arrived in Camp We were all as black as the dirt of Kansas could make us.  We laughed at each other about our different Complection   the Roads were Swept as clean as a parlor floor it was impossible to See 10 feet before one and the animal refused to go on  about dusk all was as Calm as if nothing had happened.  Thermometer in the Evening 70.
June 6 Wednesday  left Cotton Wood for Rock Creek weather warm the Road rather [?] undulating higher ranges of Bluffs or hills the first drawback to all this country is the Want of Wood and Water What can a Man do in this fine Country without wood and water   here one May Sit down and plow his [?] of wide acres of as fine land as Can be seen any where, Yet the insecurity of the Chance Satiate the [?] and one feels discouraged or Wants resolution to undertake the task.   Thermometer 80.  all well   We went on 7 miles further than we [?expected?] on to Whiskey Run.
7 Thursday  left this Whiskey Run, that is a pool of water on the prairie some twelve miles from any water except a few wells dug within about 10 Miles by Emigrant Settlers for their own [?] and not for Stock So we have to  Make our Coffee &c of this water and thankful we are in Kansas to [?] water in any That Most of the Rivers & Creeks are perfectly dry not
7 Thursday

Tuesday 12   The Weather very hot atmosphere Sultry [?lovely flowers?]
Camp [?passed?] about 7 oClock  the Horses Suffer [?] from the heat   We made about 23 Miles and Camped about 6 Miles East of the Sandhill Bluff  Which divides the prairie from the Plat Valley about [?Sundown?] a Thunder Storm rose in the West and troubled us some about ½ past 3 in the Morning the Wind shifted to the North West the thermometer fell from [?O2?] which it stood at Sundown to 50 with a strong cold wind   The Rain fell in torrents with Terrific Thunder & lightning.  Our Camp Was at once drenched and all our Bedding soaked it was a perfect deluge and of the [?] kind   The poor horses shook like aspen Leaves and we were all very cold.  determined to leave the [?]   We Harness and Start at 5  [?] for the Valley of River Plat notwithstanding it Rained & hailed in torrents with Very Strong Wind.  This was the Most disagreeable Night that We have Seen on the prairie having passed this and hills during the Storm We enter the Plat Valley just as it commenced Clearing up.  We were much pleased in the Change both of Weather & Scenery.   The Valley is a wide prairie Bottom [?bordered?] Southward by the Sand Bluffs and as far as We could See North it was no other way we found the crossing of the Stream is Marked by a line of [?Stones?] which form one its Banks it is a Beautiful Stream and now filled by the Rains it looks Majestic far handsomer than  any River we have seen on this Road.  The Valey of the Plat will Soon be filled with Splendid farms it cannot be This area here one Sees thousands of acres of perfectly Level prairie bottom ^or Meadowland  [?] and producing [?] fabulous prairie.   This is the Most inviting Spot I have yet Seen.  today we came up with one of those extremely and excessively Western Sights, a Mercantile Caravan from St Louis going for Denison City with Mcdze &c   it consisted of 75 Very large Waggons made for this trade and covered with Canvas

the prettyest plan tonight  We shall camp about 5 Miles beyond Liberty farm on the little Blue and Shale   Spend our Sunday in Nebraska   Weather wet to day Road soft
Sunday 10    5 Miles beyond Liberty farm,  here we spend our Sunday  We had one of the most drenching Thunder storms today  Water fell 3 inches in 2 hours and plenty of hail,  tomorrow's Ice cream, flooded our tent Somewhat  [?] wet the food in the Waggon  Yet we dried all before Night -the storm over  every thing seems still and beautiful   there are about 200 head of Stock on this flat Where we Camp and by Monday 8 oClock all will be gone and then again in the Evening new comers can Get with all this stir and bustle not a living soul inhabit the country except the persons employed to keep the Horses & Mules at the Station, for the Express Co.
Monday 11   today we left this Station at 8 oClock the River much Swole some 40 lots of Teams Waiting the falling of the Water.    An Emigrant farmer with Mule & horse Team forded the Stream at Several trains transited his food the other side.   We then Cut poles and laid them on our Waggon boxes and with a [?few?] crossing got safely over, altho the water was over the forward Wheels and a foot in the Waggon Box    This day we made only about 9 Miles, and had a grand Race with a large Grey Wolf but did not Succeed in overhauling him.  When he found that we were about firing up the Chase he turned about and looked at our Bull dog with evident Satisfaction.   to night we Camp on the prairie near a River with water after [?] and we have also plenty good grass - a thing now indispensible  [last line of page blurred and partly cut off]  at noon so it might find [?bread?]

I think Queen Vick Should own the Platt River for the purpose of Making all her Children Governors of Islands for my part I should Rather be the governor for State than of an Island  on the Platt [three unclear words] [?be So Common?]    Weather today very hot  Thermometer 95 and 102 in the sun [three unclear words]  We Made today 20 Miles and Camped on the Bank of the Platt East of Plum Creek [?] 13 Miles plenty of wood fuel & water tonight
Friday 15  Made an Early Start today from plum creek.  we [?hauled?] all the wagons an uniform loads a [?moderate?] of each and [?] hill or vally exhibiting sometimes a deep Ravine [?] Roads are bad and plenty of Alkali or [?] Saleratus [?] on the ground.  Plum Creek is a deep Ravine with considerable Water now after the Rain    The descent &

[?ascencion?] very Steep    We went tho without any Trouble   The [?] tonight a [?] little beef of fish and in the Morning we had as food Catfish in [?] Line.   Thermometer today 91  All well 

Saturday 16   We Start today for Cold Water Station up the Same level platt Vally  Plum Creek is considered the Main crossing of the Buffaloe but we had only farther to See any   There are but few [?put?] down this [?Gray Gr....?] of all kind is Scarce   Went thru prarie Dove & Corlis.  Roads today [?] bad lot of Saleratus encrusting.  Today we met a slight accident of the upsetting of the Small Wagon   No [?significant?] damage    Encamped [?two unclear words?] on the Bank of the Platt and at once [?] our fish lines and took some catfish.   Very high winds tonight.  Thermometer 85
Sunday 17  We spent Sunday o the Bank of the Platt near Cold Water Station  the River here is about 2 [?] wide in Cloudy [?] three Teams take a [?Loads?] on Island in the River opposite our Tents and we are told that the

they looked like a Ship at Sea When Seen on the prairie these waggons were Each draw by 5 Yoke of heavy Oxen and a lot of Mules & extra oxen driving with along with them in case of need.   there was to each Team 1 driver and to take Care of the Extra Stock Some 5 or 6 Men and 2 Capts or rather a Capt & his Mate.  I cannot give any Idea in words the grand Sight it Make on the hard bottoms of the Plat Valey.  it looked at a distance like a large City but when the Moved out of Camp the String form about 2 Miles, and much resembled Ships at Sea.  the Drivers Were principaly French Voyagers with [?] & Indian Blood in the noise they made Yelling Whipping & Swearing has no counterpart in Any part of the World that I have visited.  Reaching [?] of fort Kearney We proceed to the post office  And found 2 letters dated 1 & 2 June 1861 but no Harper's Magazine that of course Was Mis-sent just as the people of the United States Mis-sent old Buck to the White House and he or his post Master friend misspent their [?Mis....?] representative to the P.O. of fort Kearny    We camp tonight 2 Miles West of the fort.  Weather this afternoon good  Road Muddy   Thermometer 88 at 2 oClock
Thursday 14   This Morning we made an early Start.  Road heavy after the Rain.  We drove rather harder than we should have done in consequence of the near approach of the larger caravan Spoken of Above.   The Country passed through in the Platt Valley  So far soon Satisfies  No wood no [?] no water except River or worse [?].  Bad Road in Wet Weather on the other hand if these things could be Suffered in is a Beautiful Valley  river as straight as an Arrow ([?]) Rising with a Rapid current and well cut up with Islands so Much So that it would have taken Don Quixote but little trouble to Supply Sancho Panza with a fine Island.

they Say that there are hundreds on the Way what we Shall Meet daily  We were visited today by a Small Tornado  not Much Rain    no damage done John and his poney Engaged themselves much.  Thermometer 92
Wednesday June 20   We leave Fremont Slough by Fremont Spring which later is certainly a good spring of water here   We follow our Road and regular our selves plenty fine with [?pennl?] water  it looks better and tastes better than the Waters of the plat, today John had a fine chase after 3 Antelopes Making Some Very good Efforts to bring them up to the [?guns?]  it was really pretty to See him Strain the [?horisons?] of his little pony at a break neck speed perfect Master of his horse and making Some [?paid?] movements to hear his [?]  They [?] to hear them at certain points So as to [?] them taking the River in making one of those Angles he Started a large Blk Wolf   the fellow seemed as if the Horse & Rider were intruding and Sulkily [?] off.  the country to day is hilly and we cross Spurs of the Sand hills on the South Side of the plat.  at OFallons Bluff in Hackaday's Station we again come on the River bottom - here we saw to [sic] families of Indians Which we Saluted with 'How' and was answered in the Same Style we gave them a plug of Tobacco Each and after proceeding on our going a few Miles we were Met by the Chief and his Squaw on Horseback.  they Solicited presents after the Salutation of How & shaking hands we gave each some Crackers & a [?] of [?]   To Night we Camp about 6 [?Mile?] west of Ginnis' Station    Thermometer 86   this Section of the Country  appears bare  58 Returning Teams today

Indians [?travel?] there  to watch Buffaloes & Elk Antelope &c   Weather fine to day with a cold strong Wind   Thermometer 85
Monday June 18th  a fine day healthy breese  Thermometer 95 at noon  We Camped today at Cotton Wood Spring 33 Miles off our last place,  there is a fine Spring of water at this place one of the best we have Seen in crossing up in the bottom of a Dry Ravine the grass also was Very good we drove up the hills into the Ravine, and was well paid in good grass, We daily travel alone but at night we have plenty of Company   We find that altho some of [?our?] friends travel Sunday we come up with them again Saturday Night  the Sabath is good for Man & Beast too   See Very few Indians and those we See Seem to be old Men & Children  they look [two unclear words]    I think the Braves are South after the Buffaloe   We See every day some of the finest Chances to [two unclear words] by young Men of perseverence plenty of the finest Land for the taking for it will not be in market for ages and great [?] for producing corn in the Neighborhood 38⍧  Bul and [?] Egg 4/ doz  Hams 35   pork 35  a Drink of Liquor & [?] (2/[?]) and When thngs in like proportion a great trade might be done on the [?Ranges?]  the adobe Houses here are not new to Me (I have Seen them before in [?] on the Mountains here [?Mainclochy?] [?]
Tuesday June 11  today We start for Fremont Slough  the Road good a great Way  Travel on the way we meet daily about from 40 to 60 Teams  Returning they bring us Sad tidings of things at Denver

Then the pipe and presents which consisted of a little unclear cracker &c then the squaws arrived with their drove of Horses, Colt, papooses tent & [[etc.?}} The sight was novel & unique  We present each Squaw a cracker and each papoose likewise. presently by order as we supposed of their Lords and Masters the started? their cavalcade leaving Natures noblemen smoking in all the stateliness? of an Englishman cross leg on the ground, around our fine camp. they present us many letters written by learned Gentlemen of fame and also from Emigrants stating that the bearer was a good honest Indian and friendly to the Whites. one was written by General Hassining? to Good Bearer a fine old Chief apparently he felt very fond of it.  I like the simplicity of the children of the forest but hate their duplicity    they should be well treated? by Emigrants for it is their country that we travel and they certainly are unclear kindly  for ?bearing? to the White who insults them. all kind of tricks are plaid on them such as writting on their letters vulgar and impudent epithets one letter was shown me by one of the Indian chiefs the writer after stating who the Indian was  &c proceeds to call him a damn fool, thief and vagabond. I foulded up the letter and attempted to tell him it was of no use to him. The Indian seems to have no prejudice against unclear of Language, and will not I think when he can use any of our words except the salutatory "How" with that they are very prompt, and expect to be answered at once. This day wound off with a unclear Thunder Storms and flood of Rain.
Monday 25 we camped last night - at what is commonly called the first Sand Bluff. It is a spur of the Sand hill, coming down to the River the sand is very deep and awful traveling through there. The wheels sink to the hub in some places

Thursday June 21.  Roads today rather rough   the country does not look So good and pleasing as heretofore   We Camp near the Road no wood water or fuel Except what we carry with us.  Weather Sultry 
Friday June 22  We Camped today in a Ravine in the Spring of the Sand bluff not far from the upper crossing of the Platt a miserable place,  Sandy and no grass or watter of any [?] Williams & R Owens were on the watch to night and neglected their trust Suffering all our Horse to be driven away at 2 oClock in the Morning when I got up I could neither find the men nor Horses after Making a Tour of about [?3?] Miles over the Mountains I returned to 
Saturday Jun 23  Camp and called up all hands and Started in pursuit having found the tracks in a Ravine in the Mountains about 10 am Saturday Morning we found them near a Rancho about 8 Miles from the place where they had been driven for the [?purpose?] of a [?].   We then Started for the first sand Bluffs where we Shall Encamp tomorrow Sunday

   Weather pleasant Thermometer  86

Sunday June  24.  Today we are visited by an old Indian and 4 of his Children We gave the old fellow a couple of [?pipes?] and the Children a few crackers.  We encamped on the bank of the River  no fish last night nor game   Weather fine but warm and evident [?alterent?] in this P.M. [?appeared under?] a Storm in about an hour after the Visit by the Old Chief a Cloud of Indian chiefs appear on the Horizon making evidently for our Camp also a large lot of Squaws and Horses a little later and along they Soon Came to Camp  We Saluted and were Saluted with the Word 'How' and then Shaking of hands then took place

a Very Scanty growth of Blue [?] grass Which the Horses [?prefer?] with great avidity.  Weather very hot to day  Thermometer 110 at Noon.   Cool pleasant Evening we all slept well
Sunday July 1   We left our camp to day on the hills to find water grass this is the first time we did any traveling on the Sabath and Made Some 9 Miles  When we found plenty of Water and Some Grass on here in this [?] Miserable place we Spent the Sabath [?] travail on this cut off is not So great as it was on the Platt the Return parties on the [?] Newcomers   Weather today dry hot Thermometer 108 noon  last night a Strange dog (Large Blk one) came to Camp [?] having been lost by some one.   I then took him up and fed him  he Seems to be a Mix Newfoundland  he is very content with his new master    We are now 32 miles from Denver City the Rocky Mountains to the West of us  at Sun Rise this Morning present one of the most [?] Sights I ever Saw,   I have Seen and traveled Some on high Mountains, but they were nothing to this Sight, the fresh cold breese from them in Morning was very bracing   We were all delighted with the [?] & sight  the Lower Ranges of Mountains in the foreground  was thrown back as if were to form the base of the Snow Cap hights of the Snowy Range and certainly nothing in Nature have I ever seen to compare with the [?] Majesty of the Whole Range  The Sun Reflecting on the [?] of snow contrasted by the Blue appearance of the bare Rocks forms a splendid patch work of figures that defies description   

  The description given by the Returning parties of the [?Mines?] & [?] city is of the very worst [?]  they say that Mechaniks cannot get work for these [?] even and had great distress in [?] their [?]

We arrived this evening on the Bank of what is termed Sand Creek, a good name and proper. We had to dig a hole in the center of its Bed of some 3 or 4 feet to find what is usually found in other Creeks water. and having succeded We found it very sulphurous, but had to put up with it. The Horses also refused to drink until necessary and then very sparingly. this we are told is the character of all the water on this route. We took 7 Bags of grass along with us from the flats of the Platt so this night our horses had something to eat. Nothing grows here excepting Artemesia Cactus and a Weed resembling at a little distance fine grass but perfectly useless as fodder horses will not touch it. in the creek bottom cotton wood is found pretty abundantly so fuel was had this evening in abundance. We had a grand view of the Rockey Mountains to day it was a splendid sight Longs Point stood to the west of us distant by estimably? about 150 miles its summit covered with snow towering high into the clouds. Laramie Peak to the N.W. and from Line of the Blk hills   Language cannot convey the sublimity of the sight. Pikes peak stood south and seemed much further the top of the peak could only be seen raising above the high table land before us it appeared like  a small cloud touching the hills. Our course seems to be towards this point at present Road good except the Bottom of the Creek which is very deep sand 
Saturday 30 camped to day on the High hill, some 15 miles S.W. of Sandy Creek   Road good    no feed or water on the Road had to go some Miles  to the Bank of the same? dry creek and there found? a well at noon to water our selves & teams took along a Barrel of water and camped in Dry Ravine as above stated there was

the only redeeming quality was the road.  no draft    We arrived in Denver about 5 o'Clock and Camped South of the city where Again our poor horses had to put up with Very poor feed but plenty  of good spring water.  Had 2 Cents [?] or 40[?] per Ton   We at once proceded to the post office for our papers & letters but found nothing  at present the Express company carries the Mail here but in about 2 Weeks it is expected that the U.S. Mail will be delivered here at regular postage   we pay 2 [?] for sending or receiving letters by the express in addition to the postage.  quite a sum in these hard times  I can scarcely to day give a description of Denver   it is scattered over some 4 Miles that is a Square     some houses are of Brick some of Adobe some dry some frame some Canvas some Tents of [?Sheeting?] Canvas Calico & many other [?Contri.......?] to numberous to mention   all these seem scattered in every direction  there are a few pretty fair streets lots of Stores [?] Gambling Saloons dens of all kind  no churches and More Villany than can be found perhaps in any City of the World of equal extent  almost every Man has a [?] with his Knife & Revolver.  My first impressions are decidedly unfavorable of the place  & people   the Streets are filled with [?Teams?] coming in and going out giving the place a [?] appearance    Thermometer during the day from 80 to 115 the Early Morning cool
Thermometer is 60.  it is a Climate of great change Still it seems very healthy
Wednesday July 4.   This our National day we spend in Denver the part of Artilery consisting of one gun was called to use early and the firing continued at interval during the day  other demonstrations were had such as are usual with us in the States

Monday July 2  Having left Camp today we traveled over an undulating high prarie very little water and no grass except parched up little bunches  which no creatures except the Antelope can feed on   I Shot one this Morning through the Sholder still [?] it eludes our grasp.  We meet a number of the Arapahoe Indians, several of the Chiefs made a Call on us and were treated with Tobacco & as usual  The Weather to day was exceedingly sultry  The Thermometer standing 115 Most of the day late in the Afternoon  a fine  Mountain breeze Sprung up and made it very pleasant to travel  John is quite at home with the Indians  they let him Shoot with their arrows and Seems to be very fond of the paposes (pale face) it is amusing to see  him Sit down with the old chiefs Smoking his pipe   to Night We Camp on the high prairie in full View of the Rocky Mountains   the location is fine and plenty of Grass & Water for the Animals   it is about the best Camp we have found situated between 2 fresh water lakes and Miles from any [?] [?]   We should have liked to stay here Many days to feed our Horses if we could but we were precipitated to move on for Denver we met daily a number of persons returning to the States Sick of the Mines and cursing Denver [?pronouncing?] the Whole thing a Stupendous Humbug   some of our party begin to loose heart  and fear to meet their fate.
Tuesday July 3  We Started today for us Early (6 oClock) for the City of Denver our course having went for some Miles over Rolling prairies and then for 10 Miles down an inclined plain to the Valley of the Platt the Road we expected  to find no grass or water for the Horses this way or food days from [?Denver?] under a broiling Sun without find  a water
